awd_titl_txt: PREEVENTS Track 2: A fast-response wildland fire modeling framework for prediction and risk assessment
awd_abstract_narration:
Wildfires are increasingly common throughout the US and have significant impacts on populated areas. Current rapid-response management is based on empirical or semi-empirical models developed more than 40 years ago. The focus of this project is to create a Multistage Wildfire Research and Prediction System (MWRPS) that links several existing community, open source models developed. This new model has the potential to change how fire is studied, and significantly improve operational wildfire and smoke forecasting. MWRPS will serve as tool for fire professionals, urban and environmental planners, and disaster managers who need to determine the societal and ecological impacts of wildfire and smoke. As a community model, MWRPS will be available to the public to examine a variety of hazard-related issues.  In addition to graduate student and postdoctoral training, the project includes a plan for K-12 outreach through the Hi-GEAR program.

Sudden changes in flow at the fire line are crucial to extreme fire behavior and associated hazards. Because flow at the fire line can significantly impact fire spread and subsequently all wildfire behavior, prediction and simulation of coupled atmosphere-fire flow must be accurate from synoptic down to fire line scales. Accurate prediction requires the ability to model rapid synoptically-driven changes in local winds, realistically render flow in complex terrain, and capture the impacts of the fire itself on local weather. To meet this challenge, the Multistage Wildfire Research and Prediction System (MWRPS), a multi-scale model, 3D model will be developed based on fundamental fluid dynamical principles. MWRPS will have the ability to resolve buildings, trees, and land cover, to incorporate the effects of complex terrain, different vegetation types and geometries, to disperse smoke, and to represent radiation, sensible, and latent heating in the wildfire environment. Predicted wildfire properties from this model will include high resolution temporal and spatial evolution of the fire perimeter and intensity; behavior for both surface and crown fires; smoke production and dispersion in the Wildland Urban Interface (WUI) or through tree canopies (crucial for planning a proposed prescribed burn); and impacts of smoke concentrations and of heat flux in safety zones and on WUI structures. In addition to the model development, three aspects of extreme wildfire behavior will be addressed: the roles of (1) fuel heterogeneity, (2) complex topography, and (3) fire interactions. A data-driven system will be developed for atmosphere-fire models to steer simulations from a multitude of sources including: weather data, sensors, airborne fire images, and satellite remote sensing in a statistically sound manner.

por.por_cntn:
Wildfires both affect and are affected by winds that vary over a large range of scales, from small-scale turbulence, to terrain-induced flows, to the winds associated with familiar weather systems. A numerical model designed to accurately predict the behavior of wildfires needs to represent all of these scales, and to do so in a computationally efficient manner. To predict the winds associated with weather systems the model must incorporate the same observations that a numerical weather prediction (NWP) model does. To represent terrain-induced flows, it must resolve terrain features such as canyons and ridges that influence such flows. And to represent small-scale flows that affect fire spread at the scale of a fire line, a model must resolve these features as well.  Finally, to initialize the model, one needs observations of the current location of the fire perimeter.

The goal of our project was to couple a NWP model called WRF (Weather Research and Forecasting model) with QES (Quick Environmental Simulation), a model originally designed to predict near-surface, small-scale wind flow over flat terrain with buildings. By modeling in a computationally efficient way the flow in the thin  layer between the surface and WRF, this multi-scale method would give WRF the heat fluxes needed to accurately simulate wind modifications due to a fire.

WRF was coupled to a fire spread model, SFIRE, more than 10 years ago. The previous development of QES focused on improved predictions of how natural winds and urban structures interact.  This model was developed to run on a GPU (graphical processing unit), and is therefore extremely computationally efficient. To couple WRF-SFIRE and QES, new capabilities were required for QES: a module to simulate winds over terrain and within vegetation canopies, called QES-Wind, and another module to simulate the impacts of fire spread on the near-surface wind field, called QES-Fire.  In addition, a method to couple the models had to be developed.

QES-Wind contains a vegetation canopy model which can handle any distribution of vegetation. In addition, a fast response wind model was developed to compute slope and valley flows. This methodology can then be integrated with QES's diagnostic wind solver to compute winds in mountainous regions. 

The team also developed QES-Fire, a physics-based fire spread model combined with a sophisticated buoyant plume model that simulates the small-scale near-surface wind field in the vicinity of fires. This model is designed to be combined with QES-Wind.  The combination will provide more accurate and detailed lower boundary conditions to the coarser grid of WRF-SFIRE.  A prototype method to couple WRF-SFIRE and QES-Wind has been developed and tested.

The project also resulted in significant advancements in the coupled fire-atmosphere modeling capabilities of WRF-SFIRE as a stand-alone model. A predictive fuel moisture model has been implemented. The model utilizes data from numerical weather prediction to forecast the changes in the amount of water in the fuel to allow better predictions of fuel flammability, fire rate of spread, and intensity. In order to enhance air quality modeling capabilities, the coupled fire-atmosphere model has been coupled with a chemical transport model. This functionality makes it possible to simulate the air quality impacts of wildfire smoke, including the formation of secondary pollutants, such as ozone, as well as the impacts of wildfire smoke on atmospheric circulations and surface temperatures. 

 A new method for computing winds in forested regions was implemented in WRF-SFIRE. This method was tested using the data collected during an experimental forest fire and improved both the accuracy of the prediction of fire propagation as well as the prediction of plume development and smoke dispersion. Additional improvements in WRF-SFIRE were introduced to improve the representation of fire front propagation in highly heterogeneous fuels. To enable simulations of multiday large wildfires a new machine-learning method was developed which uses satellite fire detections and infrared perimeters. The method enables periodic adjustments of the fire state while preserving the atmospheric state (including smoke) consistent with the fire extent and intensity. 

This project also partially supported the development of an online forecasting system WRFx, which allows on-demand coupled fire and smoke forecasting for wildland fires utilizing WRF-SFIRE. During the project, WRF-SFIRE was used to provide modeling support for multiple experimental burns in National Forests. Fire and smoke forecasts also supported fire personnel in the planning and execution of prescribed fires. The computing resources provided by the project supported coupled fire-atmosphere forecasts for selected wildfire events during the 2020 and 2021 fire seasons. The results were shared with the public as well as stakeholders using a dedicated web portal providing forecasts of local weather and fuel moisture conditions, fire behavior, and smoke concentrations up to 48 h in advance.
